message: A sociopath's problem would come from people knowing what he really is, but if he can fool people, he's solved his problem.

Any examples come to mind?  

I feel like I've got this down to a crucial element pairing between the MC and the IC, but I'm lacking any examples to get a grasp on this.  All of what I've seen on the storyforms have Perception as the problem, not Actuality.
Got it, good example - fits perfectly (I think - see my response to your other thread).

Ha - was logging on to give an example almost completely like @MikeDerk's -- a story I hard written was similar to that - the IC Problem was Actuality - all this evidence that he had killed someone but he couldn't remember ever doing it. As long as he could keep up the Perception that he was a decent individual things were OK. He was Steadfast though (because he really was doing these things).

Well, the good news is after listening to a bunch of these podcasts, I have no fear of asking questions. Everybody seems to struggle nailing these things down. There's moments when I look at my iphone to see if it's still working because of long pauses, lol.

Here is another (possible) answer. In the back-half of "Life is Beautiful", the Actuality of being in a nazi detention camp is a problem -- but keeping of the Perception of gayety allows the MC to shield his son from the reality. (I doubt this is the actual storyform.)
"Dexter" is a good example. The Actuality is that he's a serial killer, but he has to maintain the Perception that he's a regular guy.
But is that actually Dexter's problem/solution, or his symptom/response? I think his problem is probably something a bit bigger.
In fact in that case a real problem/solution for him might be inertia/change.
Yeah in that case it sounds more like symptom/response
And, of course, you'd need to specify WHICH story in Dexter you are thinking about.  Each season seems to have a different story to explore.
